import React from 'react' export default function Introduction() { return (

This is a tool to help people take ownership over their mental health. It uses the teachings of David D. Burns, a psychiatrist and author of "Feeling Good: The New Mood Therapy". The main idea is that many of our thoughts contain various cognitive distortions. To put things in perspective, we can become aware of our thoughts and which distortions show up often for us. Then, by writing the thought down and becoming aware of the cognitive distortions present, the person is empowered to rewrite the thought in a way that puts life in perspective. This practice of writing an unrealistic thought, idenitifying cognitive distortions, and rewriting the thought in a more reasonable way can help retrain a person's mind. This self-talk helper is a tool to help individuals take ownership over their mental health in this way.

Cognitive Distortions with Descriptions:

All or Nothing Thinking: You look at things in absolute, black and white categories.

Overgeneralization: You view a negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat.

Mental Filter: You dwell on the negatives and ignore the positives.

Discounting the Positives: You insist that your accomplishments or positive qualities "don't count."

Jumping to Conclusions - Mind Reading: You assume that people are reacting negatively to you when there's no definite evidence for this.

Jumping to Conclusions - Fortune Telling: You arbitrarily predict things will turn out badly.

Magnification/Minimization You blow things way out of proportion or you shrink their importance inappropriately.

Emotional Reasoning You reason from how you feel. "I feel like an idiot, so I reallly must be one." Or "I don't feel like doing this, so I'll put it off."

"Should" Statements You critisize yourself or other people with "shoulds" or "shouldn'ts." "Musts," "Oughts," "Have tos" are similar offenders.

) }
